terms.definition: The GHG emissions associated with materials and construction processes throughout the whole lifecycle of an asset (Modules A1–A5 B1–B5 and C1–C4)
The GHG emissions arising from all energy and water consumed by an asset in use over its lifecycle (Modules B6 and B7)
The total of all GHG emissions and removals both operational and embodied over the lifecycle of an asset including its disposal (Modules A–C)
A net-zero-carbon asset where the sum total of all asset-related GHG emissions both operational and embodied over its lifecycle including disposal plus offsets equals zero
An asset product or service that produces no carbon emissions and therefore no offsetting is required. Also known as carbon zero absolute zero or gross zero
An activity that goes beyond net zero by achieving an overall reduction in GHGs in the atmosphere. Also referred to as carbon negative
GHG emissions up to practical completion excluding sequestration (Modules A1–A5)
The removal and long-term storage of CO2 from the atmosphere in biomaterials such as timber. The carbon stored in these materials is known as biogenic carbon
Process to capture the CO2 arising from fossil fuel combustion or industrial processes transporting it to a storage site and storing it where it will not enter the atmosphere
Emissions of gasses including carbon dioxide methane and water vapour that trap heat in the atmosphere. The global warming potential (GWP) of these gasses is measured in CO2e
A target that is consistent with the pace recommended by climate scientists to limit the worst impacts of climate change

Classification boundaries for an organisation's GHG emissions. Scope 1: direct emissions from owned sources. Scope 2: indirect emissions from purchased energy. Scope 3: all other indirect emissions in value chain
The use of GHG emission reductions or removals to compensate for CO2 emissions
A method to quantify the carbon emissions and other environmental impacts such as acidification and air pollution of assets or products over their whole lifecycle
A third-party verified standardised document that provides the environmental impact of a product based on the data from an LCA
Each lifecycle module (A1 A2...) describes a distinct phase in the lifecycle of an asset and modules are grouped into stages
Pre-construction stage covering project planning design and pre-construction activities
Raw material extraction and supply covering extraction and processing of materials
Transport to manufacturing plant covering transportation of raw materials to manufacturing facilities
Manufacturing and fabrication covering production processes to create construction products
Transport to project site covering transportation of construction products to building site
Construction and installation process covering all on-site construction activities including waste
Use stage direct emissions and removals from construction products such as refrigerant leakage or concrete carbonation
Maintenance covering material-related emissions from maintenance activities over reference study period
Repair covering material-related emissions from repair activities of construction products over reference study period
Replacement covering material-related emissions from replacement of construction products over reference study period
Refurbishment covering planned refurbishment or change in performance of asset planned at project outset
Operational energy covering energy use of asset over in-use stage
Operational water covering water use over in-use stage
Other operational covering user activities not included elsewhere such as vehicle use or commuting impacts
Deconstruction and demolition covering impacts during end-of-life demolition or deconstruction activities
Transport to disposal facility covering transportation of waste materials to disposal or processing facilities
Waste processing for reuse recovery or recycling covering processing of waste materials for recovery
Disposal covering final disposal of waste materials including landfill or incineration
Benefits and loads beyond system boundary from reuse recycling and energy recovery of materials
Benefits and loads beyond system boundary from exported utilities such as generated electricity or treated water
A circular economy is based on the principles of designing out waste and pollution and keeping products and materials in use through refurbishment reuse design for adaptability/deconstruction
Designing to support the continued use of an asset by allowing for and accommodating potential future adaptations
Design decisions that increase the quality and quantity of materials that can be reused at the end of a building's life. Also known as design for disassembly
Design that achieves net positive impacts on health society and the environment often being inspired by the circular low-energy systems that exist in nature
Indicates how easy a product is to separate into its material components and to convert into a new item
To use a product again while largely maintaining its original form. Unlike recycling reuse requires minimal reprocessing
A measure of how much material within a product is from a non-virgin source
Indicates how much of a product is collected and returned to the manufacturing process
The transformation of products and materials into lower quality and/or lower value products and materials
To transform products and materials into higher quality and/or higher value products and materials
Any recovery operation of suitable non-hazardous waste for the purposes of reclamation in excavated areas or for engineering purposes in landscaping
The aerobic decomposition of bio-waste in a way that fulfils a high level of environment protection and results in output which meets relevant high-quality standards
The conversion of waste into new materials and products by remanufacturing in ways that reduce demands for extracting raw materials from the natural environment
To make a new or different product and is more closely associated with recycling than reuse
A general term for treatment of materials to make them reusable
A digital tool to create and communicate three-dimensional building information and a complex repository of building information contributed by many professionals
A list of materials typically exported from BIM files to assess the embodied carbon impacts
Physical entity forming part of a network and/or system that has potential or actual value to an organization and its stakeholders
Organization that manages and is responsible for providing operating and maintaining a buildings and infrastructure network or asset
Scenario for what carbon emissions and removals would have been in the absence of planned measures aiming to reduce emissions
Structure usually enclosed by walls and a roof constructed to provide support or shelter for intended occupancy
Collection of human-made or induced physical objects located in a particular area or region
Process by which organizations sectors or other entities aim to achieve zero fossil carbon emissions
Set of actions that consume time and resources and whose performance is necessary to achieve or contribute to the realization of one or more outcomes
Data based on a unit quantity of input or output of the studied system or a process within it
Ability of value chain member to make decisions about activities that leverage carbon emissions and removals
Entity that undertakes work to construct build maintain repair replace disassemble or demolish an asset or network
Entity that creates prepares or specifies the design of an asset or network that is to be constructed maintained repaired or refurbished
Amount of greenhouse gases emitted expressed as carbon dioxide equivalent (CO2e) and relative to a unit of activity
Quantified decrease in greenhouse gas emissions specifically related to or arising from an activity between two points in time or relative to a baseline
Added benefits of decarbonization above and beyond the direct benefits of reducing greenhouse gas emissions
Ability of value chain member to support other value chain members to make low-carbon decisions
Basic physical and organizational structures facilities equipment and services needed for the operation of a society or organization
Ability of an individual group or organization to lead influence or guide other individuals teams or entire organizations
Consecutive and interlinked stages of a product equipment or service from raw material acquisition to final disposal
Actions to protect sustainably manage and restore natural or modified ecosystems that address societal challenges effectively
Combination of interconnected assets (buildings and infrastructure) that provide services to society as part of a wider system
Microbial breakdown of organic matter in the absence of oxygen
The processes such as composting and anaerobic digestion that together help to regenerate natural capital
The ability of a product component or material to remain functional and relevant when used as intended
Materials that are non-renewable on timescales relevant to the economy such as metals minerals fossil fuels
The period of time from when a product is released for use after manufacture to the moment it becomes obsolete beyond recovery
An economy in which finite resources are extracted to make products that are used and then thrown away (take-make-waste)
Keep a product in its existing state of quality functionally and/or cosmetically to guard against failure or decline
Materials that have been previously used
Excavations foundations basements and ground floors
Load-bearing elements above plinth including roof supporting structure
Installations to ensure comfort practicality accessibility and safety
The layer keeping out water wind heat cold direct sunlight and noise
The layout internal walls ceilings floors finishes doors fitted furniture
The geographical setting urban location and external works
Forms of recovery other than energy recovery including preparing for re-use recycling and backfilling
Design manufacture and use of products that use materials and resources efficiently throughout the entire life cycle
Redeveloped for similar needs and uses but meeting current regulations through restoring refinishing and future proofing
Redeveloped to accommodate different needs and/or uses with significant changes and replacement of shorter-life parts
Designed to be redeployed as modules or reused as a kit of parts while minimising any servicing
Designed to be deconstructed and reused or recycled on a part by part basis
Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method - a sustainability assessment rating scheme
Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design - a sustainability rating system
Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors - professional body providing standards and guidance
Gross Internal Area - a measure of building floor area
Royal Institute of British Architects - professional body and work stage framework
Cross Laminated Timber - engineered wood product made from layers of lumber
Forest Stewardship Council - certification for responsible forest management
Ground Granulated Blast-furnace Slag - cement replacement material
Pulverised Fuel Ash - cement replacement material from coal combustion
Global Warming Potential - measure of greenhouse gas impact
Design for Manufacture and Assembly - approach to simplify construction
Dynamic Simulation Modelling - computational modelling technique
Energy Use Intensity - measure of energy efficiency in buildings
National Building Specification - UK building specification system
New Rules of Measurements - UK quantity surveying measurement standard
United Kingdom Green Building Council - industry body for sustainable building
World Green Building Council - global network for sustainable building
Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers - professional engineering body
Glass Reinforced Concrete - composite building material
International Energy Agency - intergovernmental energy organization
London Energy Transformation Initiative - industry collaboration for net zero
Carbon stored in biomaterials such as timber from atmospheric CO2
European Standard for sustainability of construction works assessment of environmental performance of buildings calculation method
European Standard for sustainability of construction works sustainability assessment of civil engineering works calculation methods
European Standard for sustainability of construction works environmental product declarations core rules for construction products
International Standard for environmental management life cycle assessment principles and framework
International Standard for environmental management life cycle assessment requirements and guidelines
Assessment approach covering production phase from raw materials to factory gate (Modules A1-A3)
Assessment approach covering stages A1-A3 and A4-A5 up to project completion
Assessment approach covering entire lifecycle from raw materials to disposal (Modules A-C)
Assessment approach covering stages A-B-C and Module D including benefits beyond system boundary
Period of time considered for the LCA study affecting results related to in-use stage replacements
Definition of which life cycle stages are considered in the LCA study
Life cycle stage covering modules A1-A3 including raw material extraction transport and manufacturing
Life cycle stage covering modules A4-A5 including transport to site and construction processes
Life cycle stage covering modules B1-B8 including all emissions during asset operation
Life cycle stage covering modules C1-C4 including deconstruction waste processing and disposal

terms.term: Benefits and Loads Beyond System Boundary
terms.definition: Module D covering potential benefits and loads from reuse recycling and exported utilities
Calculation and reporting of carbon impacts throughout all life cycle stages of a project including assessment of benefits beyond system boundary
International Construction Measurement Standards providing cost classification system
Common unit of measurement for GHG emissions allowing representation of all GHGs associated with material or process through standard unit
Standard unit expressing GWP of greenhouse gases in terms of carbon dioxide
Concept of buildings as stores of materials that can be recovered at end of life
A finite amount of carbon dioxide that can be emitted for a given level of global warming
The total energy required for the extraction processing manufacture transportation and assembly of building materials
Energy consumed during the operational phase of a building for heating cooling lighting ventilation and equipment
The amount of carbon dioxide released per unit of energy consumed
CIBSE Technical Memorandum for embodied carbon of building services calculation methodology
International standard for corporate GHG emissions accounting and reporting
Sustainable Knowledge Asset rating system for fit-out projects
UK Building Regulations covering conservation of fuel and power
Methodology in Module D that seeks to avoid double counting benefits of reused and recycled materials
Life cycle inventory database containing environmental data for materials and processes
Inventory of Carbon and Energy database from University of Bath
Tool for the Reduction and Assessment of Chemical Impacts - LCIA methodology
Centrum voor Milieukunde Leiden - LCIA methodology used in environmental assessment
Finnish tool using generic data and EPDs with TRACI or CML methodology for building LCA
Australian tool for building LCAs compliant with BREEAM certification BIM-enabled with simple interface
Free British tool based on generic data from ICE database at University of Bath
American LCA tool using GaBi database data adapted for North American market compliant for LEED
Sustainability certification program focusing on regenerative design and net positive impact
Haute Qualité Environnementale - French environmental quality certification for buildings
Methodology for evaluating potential environmental impacts based on LCI results
Compilation and quantification of inputs and outputs for product system throughout life cycle
Economic analysis methodology evaluating total costs of asset over its operational life
Energy from sources that are naturally replenished such as solar wind hydro and biomass
The amount of energy used per square foot or square meter of floor area annually
Centralized energy systems that provide heating cooling or electricity to multiple buildings
Electricity network that uses digital technology to monitor and manage electricity flows
Technology to store energy for later use including batteries pumped hydro and thermal storage
Technology that transfers heat from low-temperature source to provide heating or cooling
Photovoltaic technology that converts sunlight directly into electricity
Technology that harnesses wind energy to generate electricity
Organic material used as fuel typically from wood agricultural residues or energy crops
Energy derived from heat stored in the earth
Energy generated from flowing or falling water
Network of natural and semi-natural features that provide environmental services
Variety of life in ecosystems including species genetic and ecosystem diversity
Benefits that humans derive from ecosystems including provisioning regulating and cultural services
Stock of natural assets including geology soil air water and living things
Phenomenon where urban areas experience higher temperatures than surrounding rural areas
Drainage solutions that manage surface water in sustainable way mimicking natural processes
Roof partially or completely covered with vegetation and growing medium
Vertical surface covered with vegetation to provide environmental benefits
Paving materials that allow water to pass through reducing surface runoff
Collection and storage of rainwater for reuse in buildings and landscapes
Treatment and reuse of wastewater from sinks showers and washing machines
Reducing water consumption through efficient fixtures systems and user behavior
Measure of pollutants in air that affects human health and environmental quality
Overall condition of indoor spaces including air quality lighting acoustics and thermal comfort
Condition of mind that expresses satisfaction with thermal environment
Use of natural light to illuminate interior spaces reducing need for artificial lighting
Physical barrier between interior and exterior environments of building including walls roof windows
Material used to reduce heat transfer and improve energy efficiency in buildings
Measure of how well building prevents uncontrolled air leakage through envelope
Area where heat flows more easily through building envelope creating energy loss
Measure of heat transmission through building elements lower values indicate better insulation
Measure of thermal resistance of building materials higher values indicate better insulation
Process of ensuring building systems operate as intended through testing and verification
Continuous measurement and tracking of energy consumption to optimize performance
Building that uses automated systems to control operations including HVAC lighting and security
Computer-based control system for monitoring and managing building services
Network of connected devices that can collect and exchange data for building optimization
Digital representation of physical building that enables real-time monitoring and optimization
Computer systems that can perform tasks typically requiring human intelligence for building optimization
Type of AI that enables computers to learn patterns without explicit programming
Use of data statistics and algorithms to predict future building performance outcomes
Process of measuring tracking and reporting greenhouse gas emissions
Total greenhouse gas emissions caused by individual organization event or product
Network of organizations involved in producing and delivering products or services
Full range of activities required to bring product or service from conception to market
Individual or group with interest in or affected by organization's activities and decisions
Environmental Social and Governance factors used to evaluate sustainability performance of organizations
Process of disclosing environmental social and economic impacts to stakeholders
Accounting framework measuring people planet and profit performance
17 global goals adopted by United Nations for sustainable development by 2030
International treaty on climate change to limit global warming to well below 2°C
Achieving net zero carbon emissions through reduction and offsetting
Ability to anticipate prepare for and respond to climate-related hazards and impacts
Adjustment in natural or human systems in response to actual or expected climate change
Efforts to reduce or prevent emission of greenhouse gases to limit climate change
Total volume of water used to produce materials and construct buildings
Total volume of freshwater used to produce goods and services
Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning systems in buildings
Mechanical Electrical and Plumbing systems in buildings
Process of supplying and removing air to maintain indoor air quality
Airflow through buildings using natural forces without mechanical systems
Airflow through buildings using fans and ductwork systems
Process of capturing waste heat for reuse in building systems
Combined Heat and Power system that generates electricity and useful heat
System providing heat to multiple buildings from central source
Infrastructure distributing heat from central sources to end users
Material's ability to absorb store and release heat energy
Materials that store and release energy during melting and solidifying processes
Science of heat air and moisture transfer in buildings
Relating to combined heat and moisture transfer in building materials
Process where water vapor becomes liquid on surfaces due to temperature differences
Material that prevents moisture vapor transmission through building envelope
Material or assembly that prevents air leakage through building envelope
Protection of buildings from weather elements including wind rain and temperature
Materials that have reduced environmental impact throughout their lifecycle
Materials derived from renewable biological resources
Materials made from post-consumer or post-industrial waste streams
Concrete with reduced carbon emissions through alternative cements or supplementary materials
Engineered wood products used for structural applications in construction
Bio-composite material made from hemp shiv and lime binder
Building technique using compressed earth in formwork for walls
Building material using bales of straw for insulation and structure
Fast-growing renewable material used in construction applications
Renewable bark material with insulating properties from cork oak trees
Fungal root structure used to create bio-based building materials
Aquatic organisms processed into building materials and biofuels
Manufacturing building components in controlled factory environments
Building method using pre-manufactured modules assembled on-site
Project delivery system focused on minimizing waste and maximizing value
Collaborative design approach involving all stakeholders from project start
Systematic method to improve project value through function analysis
Agreement where payment is based on measured performance results
Discipline ensuring functionality comfort safety and efficiency of built environment
Energy performance standard for buildings focusing on fabric efficiency and airtightness
Upgrading existing buildings to improve energy efficiency and reduce carbon emissions
Assessment of building performance after occupation to validate design assumptions
Legal requirements governing design and construction of buildings
Official approval required for building development from local authorities
Documented set of rules practices or guidelines for particular activity
Framework of policies processes and procedures to ensure quality requirements
Systematic approach to environmental responsibility through procedures and processes
Purchasing decisions that take into account environmental social and economic factors
Structured approach to managing relationships between organizations for mutual benefit
System of rules practices and processes by which organization is directed and controlled
Framework for developing communities that meet needs without compromising future generations
Demonstration that specified requirements are fulfilled through testing inspection or certification

Accountability is the unavoidable duty to explain the ways in which an individual or group has carried out or caused to be carried out the obligations placed upon itself by law a governing body or constitutional document
AECOM's policy which sets out commitment as a company to maximise opportunities for whole life carbon reductions at all stages of delivery process to monitor and report decarbonisation progress
Integrated parametric software platform compatible with industry standards focusing on high performance building design and Net Zero Carbon design optimization
Principal #1 of the PAS2080:2023 carbon reduction hierarchy - Align outcomes of project with net zero transition at system level and evaluate basic need at asset/network level
Method of primary steelmaking in which carbon-rich molten pig iron is made into steel by blowing oxygen through molten pig iron lowering carbon content
Process of recognizing and examining best practices of other organizations in same line of business and using knowledge gathered as basis for improvement
Examples of procedures policies and operational activities considered to be attainable standard which companies should strive to achieve
Assessment involving comparison between biodiversity value of habitats present within site prior to development and predicted biodiversity value of habitats after development
British Standard related to concrete providing guidance for specifying concrete mixtures and constituent materials including methods for reducing carbon emissions
Moving existing building from one location to another to extend its useful life
Supplementary cementitious material produced by thermal treatment of clay minerals used as cement replacement to reduce carbon emissions
Policy implemented by European Union to address climate change by placing fair price on carbon emissions associated with imported carbon-intensive goods
Processes that capture carbon dioxide emissions from sources and either reuses or stores it so it will not enter atmosphere
Process of using captured CO2 to cure concrete enhancing its strength while permanently storing carbon dioxide
Element or process with greatest associated carbon as identified by assessment
Professional responsible for carbon management and reporting on projects
Plan which sets out carbon management system for project or organization
Methodology for calculating embodied carbon in building services
Efforts to reduce or prevent emission of greenhouse gases or enhance their removal from atmosphere
Process of working collaboratively with groups of people affiliated by geographic proximity or special interest to address issues affecting their well-being
Using building components or materials again in their original form or for different purpose
End-of-life strategy involving demolition of building and recycling of materials
Environmental impact category measuring consumption of non-renewable energy resources
Process by which fertile land becomes desert typically as result of drought deforestation or inappropriate agriculture
End-of-life strategy involving careful disassembly of building to maximize reuse of components
Process of taking apart building or component in way that preserves materials and components for reuse
Furnace that heats material by means of electric arc used in steel production
Carbon intensity value for specific material or process expressed per unit mass area or volume
Part of organization's management system used to develop and implement environmental policy and manage environmental aspects
Environmental impact category measuring potential for nutrient enrichment in aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems
Software tool for optimizing building façade design for energy performance and carbon reduction
Building designed to allow easy rearrangement of internal fit-out and arrangement to suit changing needs of occupants

terms.term: Formation of Ozone of Lower Atmosphere
terms.definition: Environmental impact category measuring potential for ground-level ozone formation
Hydrocarbon-containing materials formed underground from remains of dead plants and animals including coal oil and natural gas
AECOM's internal platform for sharing knowledge and best practices across global offices
Engineered wood product created by bonding individual pieces of timber with durable moisture-resistant adhesives
Role responsible for approving Go/No-Go decisions on projects based on sustainability criteria
High Performance Building Design Planner - software tool for building performance optimization
High Tech Construction Environmental Consultant - specialist role in sustainable construction
Principal #2 of PAS2080:2023 carbon reduction hierarchy - Identify and adopt solutions that improve use of resources and design life of asset
Management system that integrates all components of organization into one coherent system to enable achievement of objectives
Commitments made by countries under Paris Agreement outlining post-2020 climate actions
Intergovernmental body for assessing science related to climate change
International standard for sustainable event management systems
Invitation to Tender - formal invitation to suppliers to submit proposal for goods or services
Knowledge gained from experience that can be applied to improve future performance
Global goal to limit temperature increase to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels as outlined in Paris Agreement
Level of Detail - measure of completeness and accuracy of information in BIM models
Design approach focused on creating buildings and infrastructure with extended useful life
Mechanical Electrical Infrastructure Consultant - specialist role in building services
Standard developed by NHS providing technical guidance for sustainable resilient and energy efficient buildings meeting net zero requirements
Leading LCA software vendor providing suite of LCA tools for buildings and infrastructure projects
Environmental impact category measuring potential for substances to deplete stratospheric ozone layer
Proposed addition to Building Regulations concerning embodied carbon and its reduction
Strategy involving retention of some building elements while refurbishing others
AECOM's community engagement planning platform
Framework defining how project will be organized and delivered
Professional responsible for planning executing and closing projects
Standard published by BSI that provides guidance on specific topics
To restore or renew natural systems and environments
Degree to which building components can be replaced at end of service life
Strategy involving retention of existing building structure with performance improvements
Request for Proposal - document soliciting proposals from potential suppliers
Greenhouse gas emission targets aligned with goals of Paris Agreement to avoid worst effects of climate change
Materials used to replace portion of Portland cement in concrete to reduce carbon emissions
AECOM's approach to solving for carbon systematizing methods workflows and tools to reduce emissions
Tool for tracking and monitoring decarbonisation progress across projects
Digital platform providing access to AECOM's carbon reduction tools and resources
Sustainability Carbon Operational Rating System for evaluating building performance
Highly reactive pozzolan used as supplementary cementitious material in concrete
Small and Medium-sized Enterprises
Sustainable Systems Integration Model - AECOM's framework for integrated sustainable design
Movement of structural engineers committed to climate and biodiversity emergency action
Sub-contractor or supplier providing goods or services to main contractor
AECOM's comprehensive framework for integrating sustainability across all project phases
Principal #3 of PAS2080:2023 carbon reduction hierarchy - Assess alternative solutions and adopt one that reduces whole life emissions
Specific educational initiative aimed at building knowledge and skills in particular area
Professional providing technical leadership and expertise on projects
Tool for calculating embodied carbon in structural elements

terms.term: UK Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (UK CBAM)
terms.definition: UK policy similar to EU CBAM for addressing carbon leakage through imports
Industry body promoting sustainable building practices in UK

terms.term: UK Net Zero Carbon Buildings Standard
terms.definition: Cross-industry standard bringing together net-zero carbon requirements for all major building types
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
Unified classification system developed by NBS for construction industry
AECOM's conceptual approach to achieving zero carbon design
Specific measures within AECOM's Eco.Zero™ framework for carbon reduction
Achievement of net zero carbon emissions during construction phase
Achievement of net zero carbon emissions from operational energy use
Achievement of net zero carbon emissions across entire building lifecycle
Professional responsible for coordinating net zero carbon initiatives across projects
Specific goal to achieve net zero carbon emissions by defined date
Strategic plan outlining pathway to achieve net zero carbon emissions
Systematic approach to measuring monitoring and reducing carbon emissions across organization or project
Final stage in building or product lifecycle when it reaches end of useful service life
Industry collaboration working to make London's built environment compatible with 1.5°C trajectory
Actions to protect sustainably manage and restore natural ecosystems addressing societal challenges
RICS standard providing measurement rules for cost planning and procurement
By-product of coal combustion used as supplementary cementitious material in concrete
By-product of iron production used as supplementary cementitious material to replace cement
International treaty on climate change adopted in 2015 with goal to limit global warming
17 global goals adopted by United Nations in 2015 as universal call to action to end poverty protect planet
Section of UK Building Regulations covering conservation of fuel and power in buildings

terms.term: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)
terms.definition: International green building certification program developed by US Green Building Council

terms.term: Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Methodology (BREEAM)
terms.definition: World's first sustainability assessment method for buildings established in 1990

terms.term: Chartered Institution of Building Services Engineers (CIBSE)
terms.definition: Professional engineering institution representing building services engineers
Engineered wood product made from layers of lumber boards stacked crosswise and glued together
Professional body promoting and enforcing highest international standards in valuation land economy and built environment
Framework for assessing sustainability and ethical impact of investment in company or business
Repository of project case studies and examples demonstrating ESG principles in practice
Gases in atmosphere that trap heat contributing to greenhouse effect including CO2 methane and nitrous oxide
Floor area measured to internal face of external walls including internal walls and partitions
Measure of how much heat greenhouse gas traps in atmosphere compared to carbon dioxide
Methodology for assessing environmental impacts associated with all stages of product's life

Document published by standards organization providing guidance on emerging areas
